title: Change a Tire
content: did anyone ever teach you how to change attire or did you come from one of those that's what Triple A is for kind of families well changing attire is an important skill for every driver to have and anyone can do it even inhales to get started find your Jack and your lug nut wrench and of course your spare tire you won't get too far without that in fact you should check your spare tire pressure regularly just to make sure it's fully inflated when you got a flat the last thing you need is a useless pair now the first thing to do is park your car on the most level ground you can find and then engage your parking brake if you've got a manual transmission leave it in first gear in Reverse for automatics you'll want it in park next take off the hubcap if your car has one and use your wrench to partially loosen the lug nuts you're not sure how to remove the hubcap just check your owner's manual also check to see if your car has plastic covers over the lug nuts like this one does if so then take them off first your lug nut wrench probably won't put over them and make sure you put them somewhere safe so you don't lose any of them now to take the leg that's all go in a star pattern loosening one of the lug nuts a half turn and then there's sending the one opposite to it work your way across the tire until all the lug nuts aren't screwed a half turn before you jack up the car put a heavy object like a brick in front of the wheel diagonally opposite the flat tire to prevent the car from slipping here's where the jack comes in put it under the cars frame near the wheel with the flat there's a thin lip that runs along the side of your car that's usually where the jack goes you kind of might be different though so just check your owners manual for the safest place to put your jack under the car remember it's possible for the car to slip off its jack so never get underneath the car that's only supported by a jack okay so now you've got the jack in place now insert the handle and turn it clockwise to lift the jack up if it lowers the car or won't turn try turning the handle the other way make sure you raise the jack high enough to replace your flat tire the new tire will be full of air so you'll need more room than you think remember those lug nuts you loosened earlier now you can take them off completely once the lug nuts are off you can pull off the flat tire to make sure you put the new tire on the right way look at the air valve it should be facing out to replace the lug nuts go in the same order you loosened them tighten one nut a few turns and then do one opposite until each lug nut is partially tightened then go back across from your star pattern to tighten them completely to lower the jack turn the handle slowly counterclockwise until the tire just makes contact with the ground and watch out for your feet as you lower the jack a flat foot is even worse than a flat tire make sure each lug nut is completely tightened before you remove the jack don't forget to put your jack and the object that's under the opposite tire back in your car before you drive off see how easy that was if you want to learn more about taking care of your car check out our other automotive 101 videos you can find them at sob us a.com slash sob casts

title: Change a Tire
content: hi I'm Randy Salter with Toyota West in Statesville North Carolina today I'm going to show you how to change the tire on a 2013 Toyota Corolla the first thing you want to do is to make sure the car is in park make sure the emergency brake is applied we don't want the car rolling away when we get it off the jack second thing we want to do is to pop the truck now that we're at the rear of the 2013 Corolla want to lifted what's in the trunk your spare tire jack and all the tools to use it are located under the trunk cover you lift the flap gain access to the tools first thing you want to do is to pull these tools right off the top and set them aside the second thing you want to do is to use your hand unscrew the cat in a counterclockwise motion to loosen it up and pull the jack out the third thing is to counterclockwise unscrew the spare tire and lifts the spare tire out now we're gonna pretend that this tyre is our flat tire on the side of the road here we've got our Jack that our spare tire and we've got the tools that we need this tote is your tire tool this is what we're going to use to loosen the lug nuts and tighten the lug nuts this tool we're going to use to Jack the car up and down as we need it the next step is to loosen the nuts at least one full turn because when you Jack the car up before you loosen the nuts that's how my turn that'll be making it harder the next thing we want to do is to jack the car Oh safety reasons you need to make sure that you jack it up in the correct place where you want to put the jack is right here on the two notches on the frame there's two notches in the for the rear and there's two notches for the front on this part of the frame there's a slit and the jack and that's just going to go right up on that piece of the frame now we want to take the jack handle with the loop at the end you slide it in the hole on the jack and turn clockwise until the tire just lifts the ground now the tires off the ground want to finish removing the wheel nuts and in this process you want to take the bottom nuts off first so the tire doesn't follow this way as you're taking the nuts out okay when you have all the lug nuts off just slide the tire right off okay you want to install the spare tire with this part of the hub sticking out as single push the hub on there you're gonna put the lug nuts on tapered in on the inside top first put a moon hand tight then you're going to lower your Jack lower deck counterclockwise then you're gonna tighten your lug nuts with your time now that we're done with that step everything's tight you want to physically check to make sure the tires got enough air pressure in it and it's ready to drive now we need to put the tools back in the way that we found the first thing we want to do is put the tire back in the compartment now the tire and the jack will fit back in here but your tools of course won't we'll have to put them on the top now we're going to put the jack back in this place like I mentioned before the other tools will not fit in there with the other with full-size tires so we're gonna put the tools right here in the trunk now that we put our tools back we're gonna close the trunk we've completed changing tire on the 2013 Toyota Corolla you need to proceed to the closest tire store or our gray service department here Toyota West just 20 minutes from anywhere

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack and spare tire are both stowed under an access cover in the cargo area remove the hold down securing the spare tire now you can remove the spare tire and jacking tools turn the jacks drew to the left to loosen the lug wrench and remove the wrench from the jack assembly now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of the jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire there are front and rear jacking locations on each side of the body the front locations are outlined by two triangular cutouts the rear locations by two rectangular cutouts do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jackscrew to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability ok now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jackscrew to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations remove blocks from the wheels and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Jeep com / en / owners / manuals for complete details another important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: [Music] what do you do if your car gets a flat tire you could call a tow truck and take it to an auto shop but that can be expensive and take a lot of time or you can change a tire yourself first you need to take your spare tire and Jack out of the trunk of your car if you don't have one make sure to buy one at your local auto store use a jack you need to turn your lever clockwise tighten it and pull the lever up and down to raise it up and turn the lever counterclockwise to loosen it so the jack goes down take the jack and put it under the frame of the car and you retire you want to change tighten the jack and raise it up [Music] make sure the jacks high enough to put jack stands under your car next put the jack stands under the frame of your car to secure it in the air using your jack slowly lower your car onto the stands when you have your car securely on your jack stands you next take off the hub cap you may need a crowbar to do so the next few steps you will need to use other impact with an air compressor a socket wrench or a tire iron if you use an impact or a socket wrench you will need a socket that will fit on each nut of the wheel make sure you have the right socket and take out the nuts in the wheel and always remember to wear safety glasses [Music] when you have taken all of the nuts off the wheel you next take off the bad tire [Music] put the good spare tire on the car and screw the nuts back on as tight as you can [Music] make sure that each nut is secure for the next step you can use a tire iron but you might not want to this is why you always wear safety glasses they saved this man's eyes we recommend using a socket wrench to tighten the nuts and never use an impact to put your tire back on when your spare tire is securely back on your car you next put your jack back under the frame and raise up your car until you're able to take out the stands from under your car [Music] slowly lower your car and take your check out so that you're ready to get back on the road and get to where you're going [Music]

spare may be a little doughnut size or it could be a full size tire like this one of the things we remember is if you have a flat tire on the front you're going to want to take the rear tire and put it up front if your front wheel drive or vice versa if it's other way around where you have a rear-wheel drive vehicle so let's get started most of your vehicles today actually have the tools to title: Change a Tire
content: in this video I'm going to give you the key points on how to change a flat tire safely things to remember before changing the wheel are pull over in a safe place try to park on flat solid ground make sure the handbrake is on tight and the vehicle is in park put your hazard lights on and if the vehicle is equipped with a safety triangle put that behind the vehicle to warn other motorists first remove the spare wheel jack and wheel brace from the vehicle if the vehicle is equipped with a wheel chock use it to chock the diagonally opposite wheel loosen the wheel nuts before jacking if you're having a hard time trying to get them undone use your body weight find the jacking point the jacking point is different on all makes and models so refer to your owner's manual make sure the jack is lifting nice and square if not lower and reposition do not risk it Jack the car up slightly and place the spare wheel under the car just in case the car falls off the jack and remember to Jack the car a little bit higher allowing for the fully inflated tire when trying to remove the wheel you may find it fused on with light rust some force may be needed remove the flat tire and placed under the car just in case the vehicle Falls when changing the tire never sit with your legs under the car or put your hands at the bottom of the wheel before you fit the spare wheel make sure the hub and wheel studs are clean free of dirt and grime fit the spare wheel make sure the wheel is located correctly on the hub this is extremely important some wheel nuts can go on to ways always remember to put the tapered part of the wheel nut towards the wheel itself then put all the wheel nuts on and tighten them by hand before nipping them up with the brace once the wheel nuts are nipped up with the brace you can start lowering the jack then you can tighten them properly when the car is down on the ground tighten opposing wheel nuts after each other don't go around in a circle use a star pattern now remember if your car was equipped with a space over the full-size flat tire may not fit correctly in the rear so there you go now if you have a space over like I do it's important to remember that you cannot travel over 80 km/h with it now whether you have a space saver or a full-size sphere remember to get the original flat fixed straightaway if you think this was inconvenient imagine getting a flat tire and having a flat spare

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the compact spare tire jack and jack handle are stowed under the rear load floor in the trunk lift up the load floor cover and remove the hold down to remove the spare tire now you can remove the scissors jack and lug wrench as an assembly turn the jack screw to the left to loosen the lug wrench and remove the wrench from the jack assembly go ahead now and loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of a jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire there is a front and rear jacking location on each side of the vehicle place the jack underneath the lift area that is closest to the flat tire turn the jack screw clockwise to firmly engage the jack saddle with the lift area do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle and reinstall the lug nuts with a cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Chrysler comm slash owners for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: when you notice you have a puncture do not continue driving your Toyota as this can rapidly damage both the tire and wheel stop your car safely on a firm level surface away from traffic if possible if needed set up a warning triangle and turn on the hazard lights apply the parking brake and put the vehicle in park or first gear so the car doesn't accidentally move switch off the ignition and ensure that all passengers safely exit the vehicle you'll find the spare wheel and replacement tools in the trunk the tools include a jack for raising the vehicle and a wrench to take off the nuts that attach the wheel to the car if the wheel has a hubcap used the tool provided to remove it before jacking up the vehicle use the wrench to loosen the nuts 1/2 to 1 turn these should be quite tight if you don't have the strength to loosen them by hand try using your foot next you need to jack up the car search the underside of the vehicle to find the jacking point closest to the wheel you want to replace if you can't find it check the owner's manual never put any object or any part of your body under the vehicle when using the jack once the jack is in place jack up the vehicle until the flat tire easily clears the road you can then remove all the wheel nuts and the flat tire do not touch the disk wheels or the area around the brakes as they can be extremely hot lift the spare wheel onto the hub and make sure the holes are lined up then replace the wheel nuts tightening them until they're firm lower the jack until the spare wheel touches the ground then using the wrench tighten the wheel nuts firmly in sequence once this is done lower the car completely remove the jack and put it and the tools in their proper place put the flat tire somewhere handy so you can have it fixed and replaced by a Toyota repairer if you cannot do this soon check the wheel nuts after a couple of hundred kilometers of driving to make sure they're still tight remember not to exceed 80 km/h when driving with a compact spare wheel at the Toyota authorized repairer you'll receive expert assistance and the best possible care for your Toyota insuring that your driving experience remains safe and pleasurable

title: Change a Tire
content: hey everybody transfer home in mechanic's comm today I'm going to show you how to change the tire on a 2015 golf SportWagen so unlike a lot of other Volkswagen generations that have the tool kit in with the spare tire our tool kits actually on the driver's side behind the trim cover now in order to gain access to that we turn these two handles and pull this panel off we see a styrofoam box now we actually have to undo the rubber strap and pull the box out that will give us access to all the tools that we're going to need to change a tire on our car now I did a video a long time ago on my Passat showing how to use the Jack book so I can actually went to the screw-type jack which is a hundred thousand million times easier to use than the old Widowmaker as they call it okay so in order to get the spare tire out we're going to raise the cover and fold it down like that you can see here there's a twist handle that's what secures not only the spare tire but the base block as well we're going to set that to the side we're going to pull this out of the way now you can either lay it to the side or if you really want to get it out of the way we can disconnect it by unplugging this connector right here and setting it forward in the compartment we're going to lift the spare tire out and roll it around to the side that we need to change the tire on okay a few things before we get started one make sure your parking brake is set to make sure your transmission is in park or in first gear depending on whether it's a manual or an automatic also I always recommend carrying a small 2x4 with you that you can use to place as a wheel chock I actually already have another one on the front wheel so we don't need to worry about this so let's change this tire before we lift the car up using the jack I always like to loosen all of the wheel bolts there's a small tool in your tool kit you can see here this is used to pull the wheel caps off so we're going to pull these all off instead of in a place where you're not going to lose them next we get our breaker tool and we break our wheel bolts loose nothing more than just a little bit we still want the wheel to stay on the car all right those are all loose now it's time to lift the car about 12 inches in front of the back of the quarter panel here there's a small divot it was really hard to get a picture so you're just going to have to kind of eyeball it if you run your hand along the rocker you can actually feel it that's the spot that we want to install the screw jack in now we can see that the car is quite a bit taller than the jack here so what we're going to do is by hand we're going to twist this jack up just a little bit next we're going to get the other piece to the jack which is the screw tool you'll see you'll see the little divot is actually right here now about three inches behind there you'll actually find the pinch weld of the car so now we've got the jack secured here I'm going to move it a little bit and make sure it's not going to slip out too far we take this piece here hook it in and then crank the car up now we don't need to have the car sky-high in order to change the tire we just need it high enough in order to get the back wheel or the front wheel depending on which one we're changing off the ground now that our wheels off the ground we can go ahead and change our tire out so we've already loosened all the wheel bolts now all's we have to do is just rotate them out the screw driver actually has a bit on the end where we can use it to turn these out by hand into them a little faster I recommend always setting these inside the toolkit so that one doesn't roll away on you we want to make sure we have all of them when we put our spare on now when we get to the last one the wheels got a lot of movement so what I usually do is take my foot and set it to push the wheel back onto the hub turn the last bolt out and then go ahead and pull the wheel off the car we're going to get our spare we're going to line up our bolt holes just like that and we're going to start these by hand make sure that we don't cross thread any of them a while back I did a review on a cobalt electric impact gun this would be super helpful to have in a in the case of having to change a tire but since we don't have that here we're just going to go ahead and do this we're using the toolkit only and I'm really happy that Volkswagen switched away from that old weird jack that they used to use it worked okay but it was a little tricky to get the hang of this one's a lot easier to use so now that I've got all these bolts hand tight I'm going to go ahead and lower the car down and then we're going to use our wrench and tighten it all the way back up alright our cars back down on the ground we're going to go ahead and snug these up as tight as we can and we're going to take to the nearest tire facility and get our tire either fixed or replaced all right guys that's how you change a tire on a 2015 golf SportWagen as well as golf and many other Volkswagen models if you have any questions or comments post it in the comments section below hey if you have the older-style jack check out my other video that I did on how to replace a Volkswagen tire alright guys thanks for watching and I will see you next time now I have to put this other feel back and if I bring it back like this

content: hi everyone this tire had a leaky valve stem and I tried everything to get the tire off so that I could put a new valve stem in but it wasn't easy I tried beating on it with a sledge jumping up and down on it throwing it against the ground at a funny angle but the tires bead stayed firmly pressed against the rim no matter what I did but this is the way I finally managed to get the bead broken loose so that I could put a new valve stem in I put the space saver on the car in place of the problem tire and then I got a board and used it as a ramp so that I can put the cars weight on the tire and break the bead loose from the rim that board turned out to not be strong enough so we'll try again with two boards all right there's room to get that out of there and put a new valve stem in I put a little dish soap on the valve stem to make it slide into its spot a little more easily and then I tried holding it with the pliers to keep my fingers out of harm's way but that wasn't going to work so I ended up with my fingers in there anyway and then just holding it in place with the pliers now all I have to do is get the tire back on the rim this might look a little silly but it does really almost there back on the ground so okay I need to go

title: Change a Tire
content: so you got a flat tire on your moped okay so the first thing I'm going to do is take the rear brake cable off by loosening this this bolt right here there it goes it just pops right up now I'm going to take the axle bolt off need one wrench on the other side it's one long bolt so you move the wrenches opposite each other and then once they're loose enough you can just do it by hand you don't need to take them all the way off just get them loose enough so that the wheel slides these are the tensioners you just flip them out of the way and then you can give the wheel a little tap forward at this point the chain is really loose and you can just derail the chain by moving to the side and spinning the wheel until it pops off okay so let the chain hang out of the way and you can give the wheel a little tap forward until it falls out of the dropouts so now your wheel is off you can choose to leave the bolts on or off if they're getting in your way by rattling around you can just take them off take the parts off in order so you remember how to put them back on when you go to reassemble your wheel you have the axle nut a washer chain tensioner and the entire brake assembly and then the other axle the other side of the axle just slides out in one piece okay the next thing I'm going to do is take the valve cap off and a little bolt hold it on and use my tire irons to take off this tire so the way I like to do it is you get one iron under the bead and flip it over and then if you go to either direction either side find the point where it's just kind of hanging over the rim and before it goes all the way down and touches you can find this nice little spot where you can grab it again and you flip that over take it out and try to put pressure down so the bead doesn't just kind of fall back into the rim you move over farther push the valve through your finger and get the tube out and this tube is garbage taking YouTube and there's going to be a washer and a bolt and then a second bolt you leave the washer in the first one on and you take this one off these guys are going to hang out inside the tire and this one is going to be on the outside any regular bike pump you have at home is going to work fine give it a little bit of air just enough so that it barely holds its shape and this is what you're going to want when you're installing the tire so before you put it back on you want to find out why did my tire go flat you take the whole tire off and inspect it for any nails or anything you could have picked up and then make sure there's no debris or anything in the rim so most tires have an arrow on it it says rotation so make sure you get that correct with the rotation of your wheel so you put the first half of the bead on and the bead is this part of the tire it's actually filled with like a coiled wined of metal or Kevlar or something like that and then the way I like to do this is you just put the the partially inflated tube just kind of shove it in there and then first thing you do is put the valve in and try it you just got to kind of find the hole that the valve is going to go into that goes and the bolt that came off with it originally the way I like to do it is I start opposite the valve and you can just start making sure that when you're flipping the bead over the rim just make sure you're not pinching the tube anywhere because that's the only that's the way you're going to pop it so keep flipping it over work it towards the valve you want the valve to be the last part of the bead that you're going to flip over so when you get to a point when you you can't you're not strong enough to keep flipping this thing over the rim then you take your tire iron out and what I like to do is hold the tire away from the rim with my fingers from the other side and when I put the iron on the rim get your fingers in there and make sure you're not pinching the tube with the iron and then go ahead and flip it over and then don't just rip it out after you've gone in there you want to make sure that you can come out without pinching the tube really crucial and there you go it's on we also want to make sure that your tire is seated all the way around you can see the edge of the bead on the inside of the rim and if there's any spaces where you can clearly tell that it's kind of it's sucked in to the inside of the rim then your tire has not been seated and you need to deflate it and re-inflate it until it seats itself and this looks fine so I'm going to go ahead and start putting things back together the brake assembly has a slot right here and it usually lines up with a bolt that's sticking out of the inside of the swingarm so that it's locked in and it can't spin around you want to make sure when you're installing the wheel that you put it in the correct location because if you miss if you missed a little bolt and you hit the brakes this thing is just going to spin around with your wheel and it's going to ruin it so make sure you get this slot lined up from axle brake assembly and adjuster and washer and the nut put these on loosely so you have enough room to get it into the rim take your chain and rail it and then put your chain tensioner back on with the little nub facing outwards it's the way it works is actually you can see it gets bigger and then it slides the wheel forward and back to wash them same thing on the other side you have the same three pieces again and now you can use these chain tensioners to actually move the wheel you can see that it rotates when I adjust it and what you want is you want to have the wheel straight with the bike and at the same time you want to have the perfect tension on the chain the chain wants to have about a half inch to an inch of plate so that feels about right to me and then you have to make sure your wheel straight so what I'm going to do is I'm going to tension I'm going to tension one and loosen the other and that will bring the wheel over and you do those at the same time and you do it properly you can move the wheel over and keep the tension at the proper amount which is after one inch right so I feel like I'm pretty centered here so I'm going to go ahead and tighten down the axle bolts all right looks good to me the last thing you want to do before you ride off is don't forget that we did take off the rear brake cable so install that and the way I like to do this is get the bolt ready to be tightened but still loose enough so that the cable will slide in that squeeze the assembly shut with your fingers and then let off a quarter of an inch and then go ahead and tighten and then you have a small adjuster here and there's usually an adjuster up at your handlebar level and you can fine tune where you like your brakes if you like to be able to squeeze them a lot before they engage or just a little bit so just double-check and make sure that it's the way you like it feels fine to me there you go change your tire you

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack and spare tire are both stowed under an access cover in the trunk remove the fasteners securing the spare tire now you can remove the spare tire remove the fastener securing the jack and remove the scissors jack and lug wrench from the spare wheel as an assembly turn the jack screw to the left to loosen the lug wrench and remove the wrench from the jack assembly now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of a jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire lock the left rear tire place the jack underneath the lift area that is closest to the flat tire turn the jack screw clockwise to firmly engage the jack saddle with the lift area do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with the torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations remove blocks from the wheels and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or dodge comm /en slash owners slash manuals for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: hi my name is Matt out here at Fort Worth Nissan and today we're going to show you how to put your spare on whenever you have flat tire alright first on this 17 row we are going to locate the jack and tools and the spare tire the tools and jack are going to be in this compartment right here to remove the jack you'll take it and loosen this knob right up here and it will loosen it up and you can remove it the spare tire is located on in this department right here to take it out you will loosen this nut right here until it comes all the way loose and you'll take the spare tire out before taking the tire loose you need to make sure that your parking brake is set the vehicle is in park and you're on a level surface so the vehicle does not move when you're trying to take the tire out next we're going to use the hook to hook it into the jack and then cook our crowbar into it and then raise the vehicle up all right with the vehicle raised safely up and round you're going to take all the lug nuts all the way off and then after that we'll be able to take your flat tire off and put the spare on alright after you got your spare tire on you all put all your lug nuts on and then you want tighten them all down where they're all nice and tight then you can safely lower the vehicle after the vehicle is loaded all the way to the ground you need to double check your lug nuts to make sure they're all tight before you take off thank you for watching this week's how to video do you have any comments or suggestions put them in the comment box thank you

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack spare tire and laminated instruction sheet are stowed in the rear cargo area under the load floor use the hook to hold the load floor up and out of the way remove the jacking tools and the wing nut securing the spare tire now you can remove the spare tire now loosen but do not remove the wheel bolts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of the jacking position is also a good idea if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire place the jack underneath the lift area that is closest to the flat tire the front locations are outlined by two triangular cutouts the rear locations by two rectangular cutouts do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jackscrew to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the wheel bolts and wheel remove the alignment pin from the jack assembly and thread the pin into the wheel hub to assist in mounting the spare tire position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the wheel bolts and lightly tighten them clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jackscrew to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the wheel bolts alternate wheel bolts until each one has been tightened twice maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the wheel bolts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations remove blocks from the wheels and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Jeep com / en / owners / manuals for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: if you should get a flat tire Volkswagen roadside assistance should be your first choice for changing a tire however every driver should know how to change a tire properly in the event of an emergency or if roadside assistance might not be available review your owners manual to learn the location of your jack and toolset and how to use them on your vehicle and for important safety information to begin the vehicle should be on level firm ground automatic transmissions should be in park manual transmissions should be placed in Reverse for all vehicles apply the parking brake and make sure the front wheels are aimed directly forward block the tire diagonally opposite of the tire being changed by using a wheel chock wooden block brick or some other object to help prevent vehicle movement when being raised by the jack to change the tire begin by removing the spare tire and toolkit from the trunk remove the covers from the lug bolts with the wire pin in the toolkit if you have hubcaps as opposed to alloy wheels you will use this for removing the hub cap as well now loosen the lug bolts with the wrench before raising the vehicle with the jack do not loosen the bolts while the vehicle is raised as the motion may knock the vehicle off the jack the bolts are loosened counterclockwise if you have a locking wheel bolt be sure to use the bolt adapter key in your toolkit place the jack at one of the lift points marked on the rocker panel use the lift point closest to the wheel being changed crank the jack until it makes firm contact with the RHIB under the rocker panel and make sure the base of the jack is securely flat on the ground continue cranking the jack until the wheel clears the ground make sure you have enough clearance for the fully inflated spare tire but do not raise the vehicle higher than necessary remove all of the loosened lug bolts and set them aside remove the flat tire and place it in the trunk lift the spare tire on to the wheel hub bolts replace the lug bolts spin them down but do not tight them yet Snug them slightly lower the vehicle to the ground and remove the jack be sure to crank the jack all the way back down so that it fits in the foam insert now be sure to tighten the lug bolts but do not tighten them sequentially tighten any bolt first then move to the bolt diagonal to it move around the bolts in a star pattern until all bolts are completely secured then repeat the pattern one more time ensuring they are fully tightened if you have a torque wrench tighten them to the specification found in your owner's manual if not be certain to have the torque checked by your Volkswagen service department as soon as possible remove the wheel chock or block and replace the toolkit and the trunk securely if your spare tire is a compact spare do not exceed the speed limit noted on the tire this is a temporary spare only and the original tire should be replaced as soon as possible we hope you never experience a flat tire if you do change your own tire be certain to review your owners manual for important information and warnings

now loosen the lug bolts with the wrench
before raising the vehicle with the jack
do not loosen the bolts while the
vehicle is raised as the motion may
knock the vehicle off the jack the bolts
are loosened counterclockwise if you
have a locking wheel bolt be sure to use
the bolt adapter key in your toolkit
place the jack at one of the lift points
marked on the rocker panel use the lift
point closest to the wheel being changed
crank the jack until it makes firm
contact with the RHIB under the rocker
panel and make sure the base of the jack
is securely flat on the ground continue
cranking the jack until the wheel clears
the ground make sure you have enough
clearance for the fully inflated spare
tire but do not raise the vehicle higher
than necessary remove all of the
loosened lug bolts and set them aside
remove the flat tire and place it in the
trunk lift the spare tire on to the
wheel hub bolts replace the lug bolts
spin them down but do not tight
them yet Snug them slightly lower the
vehicle to the ground and remove the
jack
be sure to crank the jack all the way
back down so that it fits in the foam
insert now be sure to tighten the lug
bolts but do not tighten them
sequentially tighten any bolt first then
move to the bolt diagonal to it move
around the bolts in a star pattern until
all bolts are completely secured then
repeat the pattern one more time
ensuring they are fully tightened if you
have a torque wrench tighten them to the
specification found in your owner's
manual if not be certain to have the
torque checked by your Volkswagen
service department as soon as possible
remove the wheel chock or block and
replace the toolkit and the trunk
securely if your spare tire is a compact
spare do not exceed the speed limit
noted on the tire this is a temporary
spare only and the original tire should
be replaced as soon as possible
we hope you never experience a flat tire
if you do change your own tire be
certain to review your owners manual for
important information and warnings

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the scissor type Jack and tire changing tools are located in the cargo compartment behind a trim cover on the left rear trim panel the spare tire is stowed underneath the rear of the vehicle and is held in place by a cable winch mechanism fit the jack handle extension over the drive nut located in the rear cargo area inside the vehicle use the lug wrench to rotate the nut counter clockwise until the spare is on the ground with enough slack in the cable to allow you to pull the tire out from under the vehicle when the spare is clear tilt the retainer at the end of the cable and pull it through the center of the wheel now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning into the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of a jacking position is also a good idea if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire you'll need to assemble the jack and jacking tools by connecting the jack handle driver to the extension then to the lug wrench for the front tires place the jack just to the rear of the notch on the body weld seen behind the wheel to be changed for the rear tires place it under the axle by the wheel to be changed do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle and reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum efforts should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Jeep comm / owners for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack and spare tire are both stowed under an access cover in the cargo area remove the hold down securing the spare tire now you can remove the spare tire in jacking tools turn the jack screw to the left to loosen the lug wrench and remove the wrench from the jack assembly now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of the jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire there are front and rear jacking locations on each side of the body the front locations are outlined by two triangular cutouts their rear locations by two rectangular cutouts do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations remove blocks from the wheels and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Jeep comm slash owners for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: hi my name is Ralph and I'm a service technician at David mas Toyota and today I'd like to show you how to change your vehicle's tire in the event of a flat this particular vehicles spare tire is located in the rear of the hatch to access it we need to open up the back latch compartment where you'll find your spare tire and all the tools that you will need to change your flat fire remove these covers from the vehicle so you'll be able to remove the tire once these covers all remove we should be able to remove the spare tire easily in this vehicle the jack is located in the same compartment with the spare tire remove the locking mechanism on the side which is in this case a rubber band which hooks into this piece of plastic here pull that to the side and slightly unscrew the tensioner and you can remove the jack after that the jack tools and spare tire lug nut tool is located to the right of the spare tire in this vehicle on this particular vehicle the lifting location is located just to the front of the rear tire on the bottom of the rocker pannel is an arrow which will show you the location of the jack when lifting the vehicle the jack should be put on the pinch weld so it does not slide out check to make sure that the jack is still located on the pinch weld after the vehicle starts to race once you've accomplished that proceed by lifting the vehicle slowly make sure that you have firm ground to place the jack on before you start the jacking procedure while the tire is still touching the ground remove the hubcap and loosen the lug nuts slightly when the lug nuts are loosened slightly you can continue to raise the vehicle at this point we can remove the lug nuts by hand carefully remove the tire from the vehicle your spare tire is now ready to install proper pressure for spare tires is located on the sidewall every maintenance visit that you accomplish you need to make sure that the tire pressure is filled properly install the spare onto the lug studs and start by just catching the lug nuts onto the threads spin the nuts to the rim of the tire so that they are snug by hand and then grab your lug nut tool and snug slightly at this point we could lower the vehicle down so that the tire is just touching the ground take your lug nut tool and retighten the nuts using about 50% of your body's weight changing a flat tire there's a simple test that can be done but it needs to be done safely it is important that you look at your vehicles on your mat owner's manual to make sure that you're doing the operation correctly and safely

title: Change a Tire
content: oh hello I thought I'd do a quick video on changing the tires on my K 16 I've done tire changes on other bikes but I thought it more appropriate do one on my own here we go we're starting with working on the ground as opposed to a lift to make a little simpler take the side case off I also like to take off the exhaust on the right hand side it's only two bolts there's one at the bracket at the rear then there's a bolt on the clamp underneath and this makes getting the rear wheel off a little easier some folks like to put a block under the center stand to lift the bike a little higher so you can weasel the wheel oh I prefer to do it this way the exhaust pulls right out next up is to get the bike into Top Gear by gently rocking the wheel back and forth while you shift the lever with your hand now in sixth gear the wheel is pretty solid when you try to spin off these bolts which are on they're reasonably firm and in the interest of time I use my electric wrench to loosen the nuts all the way I like to empty the air out by removing the core of the valve and and then popping the beat up on my Nomar tire changer now you've seen me change a tire before if you've watched my videos I've done I think a couple sport bike tires in a cruiser I think a Harley Road King the process is the same some tires are easier than others I find the BMW rear ones are a little tough because there's a low drop center but I eventually got it on and while the wheel is off I take the time to clean it up because it's a whole heck of a lot easier to get those folks with the cloth now than when it's on the bike also from nomar is a set of adapters for a BMW wheel for my balancer so you basically screw one cone on run it through the center of the wheel and then screw the other cone on from the other side to lock it Center it in place and it works brilliantly the balancing process this one actually didn't need a lot of weight at all considering the size of the tire very well and like the wheel I get an opportunity to clean some areas that are easy to get to right now for simple interest sake here's the driveline lash in the bike which I find to be a lot and also a neat feature which I just noticed an adjustable mud flap there you go once I get the wheel centered over the holes it's a matter of throwing in the nuts and then torquing them with my torque wrench I'll go back in a week or so and retorque them after I've driven a short drive and once again I'm cleaning up areas that I would otherwise be very difficult to get to the exhaust goes right back in the way it came out it's takes a little finesse you have to get the pike into the receiver from the header and then you also have to guide the bracket into a finger which I put a little grease on to help out and once it's on just tighten up the bolts you're good to go and that's it for the rear so I spin the bike around to do the front now we need to hold the front in the air and I just wanted to show you if I was to sit on the passenger seat I can almost Teeter the bike up but I'm going to put a jack under the engine up front hold the front end in the air so I start first of all by unclipping the ABS line from the brake line and then I remove the fender now I forgot to do this early on so but you do remove the fender right now for simple bolts then off comes the caliper retainer bolts and then I zip tie the caliper out of the way so I can pull the wheel off but I don't have any weight on that brake line do the same for the other side and I also loosen the clamp up on the right hand side of the axle so I can spin it once that clamp is loosened I can loosen the axle itself it loosens here from the right side the left side is the retainer bolt once I get the axle loosened I can actually loosen the pinch on the left side which I can pull the net a little bit get the wheel out just like I'm doing here makes it a little easier wheel rolls rate a second verse same as the first cleaning up areas that are difficult to get to otherwise after installing the new tire I clean up the brakes with brake disk cleaner very very important and next I grease the axle makes a little easier going in and preserves the metal once the axles through I tighten the pinch bolt on the left side so I can screw the axle into the receiver now to get the calipers back on the disks I have to open them up a little bit with an old screwdriver do this very very gently because it's forcing fluid back up the line and I reclip the ABS line and I also put on a tiny little zip line that I took off earlier and here I go with my torque wrench I start with the brake calipers then I move down to the pinch bolt torque that and then I follow that up with torquing the axle and after the axle is torqued I torque the pinch bolt on the right side and after everything is torqued up with the fender on and I go back up and pump the front brake to build pressure back up because that can be a real eye-opener the first time you go out for a drive if you haven't done that anyway fairly quick job nice and easy until next time

content: we rely on our smartphones for everything these days it's like we're to Syria what's that word for when you rely on things too much dependent nevermind I already thought of it but what if your phone dies or falls in the ocean I'm Kara dougherty and through my own personal stories I'm gonna teach you some survival skills for when you don't have Google to bail you out it's Sunday and I'm driving home from a family reunion and replaying a bizarre conversation I have with my uncle about why squirrels can't burp I wonder squirrels can fart when suddenly damn it it's a flat tire I pull my car off the road I grab my phone the battery is at four percent i call triple-a when suddenly the worst thing in the world happened my phone dies I reached my car charger then remember I lent it to my brother when he went to six flags no why am I such a nice person I sent my car and cry for exactly three minutes I tried to fix the flat tire with my mind I think about death then I think about Beyonce what would she do she wouldn't cry she'd put on a power suit and be all like you were a strong independent woman I'm going to be a strong independent woman I open the glove box I look for the car manual to get instructions then remember that I used it a few weeks ago to crush a giant bug in the driveway and threw it out because it was covered in gross bug guts I banged my head against the window 10 times on the tenth bang I suddenly remember that one time in driver's head when we learned the world's most annoying rhyme ever it went don't let your life become dire here is how you change a tire I high-five myself I suddenly know what to do I need a jack a wrench a spare tire I have all of those things it's time to get dirty I turn off my car put on my hazards pop the emergency brake am on a flat surface check I look for rocks to put in front of the tires I see one that looks like a boy I made out with on a 7th grade trip to pull the plantation these will keep me safe I take out my tools then to spare I removed the hubcap I grab the wrench and clamp it around the lug nuts I remember more from the driver's ed class righty tighty lefty loosey I go left for loose they're really tight so I stand up put my foot on the wrench and use the weight of my body is that gum on my true no time I loosen the lug nuts but I don't take them off I grab the jack put it on the same side as the flat tire i turn the liver clockwise the car races up off the ground and I feel like a superhuman with superhero strength I take the loose lug nuts and put them in my pocket I pull off the flat tire I take a quick break and snap in an old granola bar that I found at the bottom of my purse I put the spare tire onto the wheel pop the lug nuts right back on don't tighten them all the way says sean sean was the name of the driver's ed teacher I lower the car with a jack remove it tighten the lug nuts righty tighty I put the flat tire in my trunk I put the rocks back where I found them and say goodbye to the one that looks like the boy I made out with on a 7 third trip to Plymouth Plantation I scrape the gum off my shoe turn my hazards off release the emergency brake start the car drive away dirty smiling and proud and there you have it now keep in mind that all cars are built differently so always refer to your car's manual when possible and make sure to always keep the following items in it a jack spare tire flashlight or flares water granola bars hand sanitizer a rag wd-40 phone charger and a survival song playlist with at least five Beyonce tracks on it be sure to download today's survival tips with easy step-by-step instructions save it on your phone and print it out to keep in your car you

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack and spare tire are both stowed under an access cover in the cargo area remove the hold down securing the spare tire now you can remove the spare tire in jacking tools turn the jack screw to the left to loosen the lug wrench and remove the wrench from the jack assembly now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of the jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire there are front and rear jacking locations on each side of the body the front locations are outlined by two triangular cutouts the rear locations by two rectangular cutouts do not raise the vehicle until you are sure the jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations remove blocks from the wheels and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Jeep comm slash owners for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: how to change a tire you will need a flat tire a spare tire a jack and a lug wrench step 1 locate your car spare tire and tool kit these usually reside under the floor of the trunk simply lift up on the pole tab in the floor to gain access to and remove the tire and kit step 3 take the water and you can loosen all five lug nuts just enough so they'll be easier to take off completely once you get the tire jacked up note if one of your lug nuts is a wheel lock you will need to put the wheel lock adapter on the lock and then use the lug wrench to loosen the lug step 4 look underneath the car to find the jack point nearest the flat tire this is usually marked by an arrow on the underside of the car step 5 place a jack underneath the car and from the handle to raise it up enough so that you can visually line up the jack and the jack point step 6 as you continue turning in a clockwise direction you will start to see the flat tire slowly rise up step 7 once the tire has good ground clearance and the jacks tension is further increased you can use the wad wrench to remove the lugs completely step 8 once all the lugs have been removed grasp the flat tire firmly and pull it straight out from the car step 9 take the spare tire and line it up with the five mounting points on the hub once the spare has been attached take the lugs and rebuilt them into their proper positions using the wand reg just as before after you've tightened up all the lug nuts sufficiently you're all set just remember to place the flat tire in your trunk and put all your tools away before setting up you

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack and lug wrench are located in the rear storage compartment to remove the spare tire from the carrier remove the tire cover if equipped and remove the lug nuts with the lug wrench by turning them counterclockwise now you can loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of a jacking position is also a good idea if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire you'll need to assemble the jack and jacking tools by connecting the jack handle driver to the extension then to the lug wrench carefully place the jack under the front or rear axle tube as shown do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle and reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum efforts should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Jeep comm slash owners for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the scissor type Jack and tire changing tools are located under the driver's seat the spare tire is stowed underneath the rear of the vehicle and is held in place by a cable winch mechanism fit the jack handle extension over the drive nut located in the rear cargo area inside the vehicle use the lug wrench to rotate the nut counter clockwise until the spare is on the ground with enough slack in the cable to allow you to pull the tire out from under the vehicle when the spare is clear remove the knob or plastic molded nut from the retainer at the end of the cable and pull it through the center of the wheel now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you are parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of the jacking position is also a good idea if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire the front and rear jacking locations are indicated by the triangular lift position indicators located on the side of the vehicle do not raise the vehicle until you are sure the jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts in wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum effort should be used to tighten the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the Jack tire and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD for complete details and other important safety information

remove this since you probably don't have a rubber hammer or deadblow handy we'll install one lug nut on a couple of threads and kick back against the tire to try and free it from the hub but be careful because that jack is not incredibly stable underneath and we don't want to knock the vehicle off the other method in extreme situations is to use the other spare tire as a hammer once the wheel and tire is loose from the hub remove that lug nut again and remove the wheel and tire install your spare tire as well as your lug nuts as tight as you can before lowering the vehicle once the title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the jack and jack tools are stored under the front passenger seat to access the jack and jack tools you must remove the plastic access cover located on the side of the seat to remove the cover pull the front part of the cover closest to the front of the seat toward you to release a locking tab once the front of the cover is loose slide the cover toward the front of the seat until it is free from the seat frame remove the jack and tools by removing the wing bolt and sliding the assembly from under the seat remove the spare tire before attempting to jack up the truck attach the wheel wrench to the Jack extension tube insert the tube through the access hole between the lower tailgate and the top of the bumper and into the winch mechanism tube rotate the wheel wrench handle counterclockwise until the spare tire is on the ground with enough cable slack to allow you to pull it out from under the vehicle when the spare is clear tilt the retainer at the end of the cable and pull it through the center of the wheel now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground now make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the tire diagonally opposite of the jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle making sure the valve stem is facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly now reinstall the lug nuts with shaped and toured the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum efforts should be used for the final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or Ram trucks comm /en slash owners slash manuals for complete details and other important safety information

title: Change a Tire
content: fixing a flat tire is the most likely mechanical problem you'll have to deal with on your bicycle and therefore the most important repair to know how to do so today we're going to show you how to fix a flat tire you'll need four things to do this job an air pump a spare tube tire tools and a shop towel for cleaning up after the job the first step is to remove the wheel and we've got another video you can watch on that make sure all the air is out of the tube then take two tire tools and insert them a couple of inches apart under the edge or lip of the tire called the bead push them down together and a little bit of the tire will come off at this point you can slide the second tire tool around the entire circumference of the wheel and it will disengage the bead from the rim now you've got half the tire off to get the second side of the tire off you'll have to put the wheel on the ground this step is a three-part move pull up on the tire pull it over the side of the rim and push down the tire should pop right off pull the tube out on the tire toss it aside and we'll go into inspecting the tire you want to be sure that whatever caused the flat is no longer in the tire the outside of the tire can be inspected visually while we simultaneously feel the inside you can feel small sharp objects in the tire better than you can see them although you'll rarely be cut a light touch is recommended in this case we can both see and feel the staple that caused our flat however you won't always find what caused your flat I'll pull this out and we'll go into the next step now put a little bit of air in the tube note that the thumb lock on the pump is pulled up in order to make a good seal a little air in the tube gives it some shape and makes it easier to handle now put the tube in the tire locate the valve stem at the tires label this gives you a reference point for matching the hole in the tube with the hole in the tire so if you flat again you can inspect the tire for damage at that point now it's time to reinstall the tire start by inserting the valve stem in the rim be sure it's perpendicular to the rim and not cocked sideways at an angle first install the back bead by simply feeding it on with your hands a little bit at a time this part is easy until you get toward the end the last few inches get harder just use your thumbs and push a small part of the bead on at a time the tire will pop right on at the end continue with the second or top bead just like on the first bead feed a little bit of tire on at a time with your thumbs you want to avoid using tire tools to reinstall the tire if you can it's too easy to puncture you know tube using them you'll see that the farther you go the harder it gets to put the tire on as it gets harder work with smaller and smaller sections of the tire make sure as you go that the tube stays up inside the tire that it doesn't get between the bead and the rim at this point let the air out of the tube that we began with also try using different parts of your hand to roll the bead over the edge of the rim now we're really getting to the tough part but again just work with tiny amounts of the tire of time all of a sudden the tire will pop on at the last moment and you're home free now we come to the final phase of our flat tire repair which is inflating the tire get a good grip on your pump so as not to damage the valve stem while pumping inflate the tire to be somewhat firm remove the pump with a quick pop so you don't damage the valve stem again before inflating to full pressure examine the bead
