title: Change a Tire
content: step one when changing a tire it is important to pick a location with a solid level ground to ensure the stability of the vehicle when being jacked up in our situation we are on concrete so we will not have to worry about that however if you are in an emergency situation like your tire blew on the highway pull over to the right-hand shoulder of the road and turn your hazard lights on make sure that your vehicle remains on the concrete portion if a car is jacked up on the sand or dirt portion of the shoulder the jack will sink which can cause damage to the vehicle as well as threatening your safety if you drive an automatic put the vehicle in park and apply the emergency brake if you drive a standard vehicle place the car in first gear and apply the emergency brake step 2 locate the necessary tools needed to change a tire on your vehicle some vehicles require a locking wheel nuts before traveling ensure that you are aware of the location of this tool without it you will not be able to remove the locks lug nut the most common storage area for these materials is the trunk of the vehicle lift the carpet and proceed to remove the spare tire and the tire iron most vehicles will have the jack assembly underneath the carpet as well but in the case of this vehicle type is stored in a compartment on the left hand side step 3 start with the jack by placing it under the frame or to the tire that you need to be changed it is important to ensure that the jack is contacting the frame directly to avoid damage to the side skirt the majority of modern vehicles have a designated area near each wheel well the designated area is usually a pinch weld in this case it is an indent if you drive a truck or older vehicle there may not be a pinch weld available if this is the case Jack the vehicle up from the frame step 4 proceed to raise the jack onto the pinch welds or frame until the car is firmly supported without actually being raised into the air at this time make sure that the jack is firmly planted onto the ground so that it will not shift step 5 locate the lug nuts on your vehicle if your vehicle has hubcaps or a center cap you may have to pry them off depending on the design from here lug nuts should be loosened but not completely removed as you can see the lug nut on the far right is a locking lug nut this is why you will need the locking key and able to remove it from here lug nuts should be loosened but not completely removed breaking the resistance of the lug nuts may take quite a bit of force depending on how tight they are step 6 fully raise the car off the ground by pumping or in this case cranking the jack the amount of clearance that you want between your tire and the ground should be enough that you can freely remove the tire step 7 remove the lug nuts completely off the hub of the vehicle this may take some time be patient a quick tip is to ensure that you remember where you put the lug nuts there's nothing worse than losing the lug nuts when you're trying to put the tire back on step 8 remove the tire there may be some resistance when trying to take off the tire this is often the case when it is winter and water freezes between the wheel and the hub don't be afraid to give it a good nudge or kick step 9 take the spare tire and place it onto the hub matching the holes on the wheels to the wheel studs step 10 place the lugs onto the studs of your tires proceed to hand tighten the lug nuts until they are snug again this may take some time be patient step 11 tighten the lug nuts securely for this five lug assembly the procedure in tightening the lug nuts will be a star pattern to ensure that the wheel is flushed with the hub assembly if you don't do the star pattern you could run the risk of your wheel falling off step 12 lower the jack bringing the car onto the ground and fully tightening the lug nuts tighten them as much as you can but not over tightening them preventing you from removing the lug nuts in the future if you purchase a new wheel assembly it is best to have it installed professionally so that it can tighten the wheel to specifications step 13 put all the materials and tools used back in their application

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the scissor type Jack and tire changing tools are located in the rear cargo area below the load floor rotate the thumb screw on the jack to loosen the assembly and remove the jack from the bracket the spare tire is stowed underneath the rear of the vehicle and is held in place by a cable winch mechanism fit the jack handle extension over the drive nut located under a plastic cover at the center rear of the cargo floor area just inside the lift gate opening use the lug wrench to rotate the nut counter clockwise until the spare tire is on the ground with enough slack in the cable to allow you to pull the tire out from under the vehicle when the spare is clear pull the metal stamping toward you until you can rotate the metal stamping and push it through the hole in the plastic plate and wheel now pinch the three short and two long tubes to remove the protective plate from the steel spare wheel now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure your parking a firm level surface avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of a jacking position is also a good idea if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire assemble the cover on top of the jack and attach the lug wrench to the jack tool with the hook for the front axle place the jack and protective cap on the body flange just behind the front tire as indicated by the triangular lift point symbol on the sill molding for a rear tire place the jack and protective cap on the flange rearward of the hoist rear tie-down bracket just forward of the rear tire as indicated by the triangular lift point symbol on the sill molding do not raise the vehicle until you are sure the jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the Jack screw to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle and reinstall the lug nuts with the cone shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum efforts should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations remove blocks from the wheels and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or dodge comm slash owners for complete details and other important safety formation

title: Change a Tire
content: hello welcome to tread life my name is Chris and I'm Darlene today's topic how to change a flat tire whether you're in your driveway or installing a spare after a flat on a busy road changing a tire can be intimidating but with the right tools a few tips and a little know-how it's something you should not be worried about so if you have a flat tire here's what you do you pull over to a safer spot on level ground you put on your hazard lights you set your parking brake you put out that safety triangle and then Chris if your safety kit has wheel wedges always use them you never want your car to roll when it's on the jack if your front tire is flat place it behind the rear tire if the rear tire is flat place it in front of the front tire so now we're very safe the first thing we want to do is to loosen those lug nuts and they may be on really tight so don't be afraid to put some muscle in it always push down never pull up and the tip of the day remember lefty loosey righty tighty and next up is placing the jack always consult your owners manual before you place the jack there are strict instructions on where the car is reinforced for proper jack placement placing the jack in the wrong place can damage your vehicle's body and safety tip number one never put your arms or legs or any part of your body under the car while it's on the jack now you just need to raise the vehicle until the tires are just off the ground we're using this traditional scissor jack put the crank handle into the fisheye and rotate clockwise now it's time to remove the rest of the lug nuts and then just slide that flat tire off take the spare tire and mount it on the lug bolts just line them up and gently push the spare on next step is to tighten the lug nuts all the way by hand don't use the wrench quite yet once on double check each lug nut to make sure they're as tight as possible we're going to use the jack to lower the vehicle so the spare tire is just resting on the ground but the full weight of the vehicle isn't on the tire yet now we can use that lug wrench to tighten the lug nuts the rest of the way always tighten the lug nuts with a crisscross diagonal pattern now we can lower the jack all the way down and give it one final tug on those lug nuts now stow all this equipment before you hit the road while all this stuff will get you by it's a really good idea to have gloves flashlight and a raincoat in your kit as well before you get going give a quick check to your spare tires air pressure if it's under the recommended amount drive slowly to the nearest service station and give it some air if you changed your tire because of a puncture it's important to go straight to your tire technician he or she can let you know if that tire is repairable or it needs to be replaced remember a spare tire is not designed to drive high speeds or long distances see that wasn't so bad no not bad at all see you next time you

title: Change a Tire
content:
How to Change a Flat Tire. Many people belong to a roadside-assistance
service, but if you're stuck in a remote area, you'll want to know what to do. You will need A spare tire A lug wrench A
jack Bricks or large rocks Roadside flares Reflective triangle A tire-pressure gauge
A canned tire sealant and a locking lug nut key. Heavy tires, elevated and unstable vehicles,
and nearby traffic can make changing your own tire extremely dangerous. Be careful, and always check your owner's
manual first—directions may be different depending on the year, make, and model of
your vehicle. Step 1. Make sure the car is parked on a flat, level
surface far from any oncoming traffic, and engage the emergency brake. Turn on your hazard lights, and if you have
roadside flares or a reflective triangle, use them to warn other drivers that you're
working on your vehicle. Consider keeping a canned tire sealant in
your emergency kit. If your tire has only been slightly compromised,
the sealant may patch it long enough to get you to the service station. Step 2. Find heavy objects—like bricks or rocks—to
block the wheels. Place them in front of and behind the tire
that's diagonally across from the one that went flat. If you have plenty of rocks, block both wheels
on the opposite axle. If you have a digital camera (or a cell phone
with a built-in camera) snap a picture before you start disassembling everything. That way, you'll have a ready reference guide
of how things should look when they go back together. Step 3. Lay out your spare tire, jack, and lug wrench. Many tires feature a locking lug nut to guard
against theft. To remove, use the special key tool—the
car's manual will specify where it's located. Step 4. Most lug nuts follow the righty-tighty/lefty-loosey
rule. Attach the lug wrench to a nut, and turn the
wrench counterclockwise. Repeat with each lug nut until all the nuts
are loosened. Step 5. Refer to the owner's manual for the best spot
to place the jack—typically along the frame, very close to the flat tire. Jack the car up until the wheel is off the
ground. Never get under the car when it's on a jack. Since it's fairly unstable in this position,
keep other people away until the car is safely on the ground. Step 6. Remove the lug nuts one at a time, and keep
them together in a spot where they won't roll away or disappear. Then remove the flat. Step 7. Mount the spare tire onto the wheel lugs. You may need to jack the car up some more
to slip on the spare tire. Check the tire pressure on your spare regularly. That way, it won't be flat when you need it. Step 8. Replace one lug nut at a time. Begin tightening each by hand, then continue
with the lug wrench. Lower your car to the ground, and finish tightening
the lugs in opposite pairs, to ensure uniform pressure. Once you're done, replace the hubcap. Step 9. Remove the objects blocking the wheels, and
place the tools and the flat tire in your trunk. Step 10. Your wheel is ready, but you won't be able
to drive as quickly on a spare. Check your owner's manual or the tire itself
to determine the spare's top speed, and get yourself to the nearest garage so they can
patch or replace your tire! Did you know In Texas Hold 'em, a "flat tire"
means you were initially dealt a jack and a four – in any suit.

transcript.text: How to Change a Flat Tire.

Many people belong to a roadside-assistance
service, but if you're stuck in a remote area,
you'll want to know what to do.

You will need A spare tire A lug wrench A
jack Bricks or large rocks Roadside flares

Reflective triangle A tire-pressure gauge
A canned tire sealant and a locking lug nut
key.

Heavy tires, elevated and unstable vehicles,
and nearby traffic can make changing your
own tire extremely dangerous.

Be careful, and always check your owner's
manual first—directions may be different

depending on the year, make, and model of
your vehicle.
Step 1.

Make sure the car is parked on a flat, level
surface far from any oncoming traffic, and
engage the emergency brake.

Turn on your hazard lights, and if you have
roadside flares or a reflective triangle,

use them to warn other drivers that you're
working on your vehicle.

Consider keeping a canned tire sealant in
your emergency kit.

If your tire has only been slightly compromised,
the sealant may patch it long enough to get
you to the service station.
Step 2.

Find heavy objects—like bricks or rocks—to
block the wheels.

Place them in front of and behind the tire
that's diagonally across from the one that
went flat.

If you have plenty of rocks, block both wheels
on the opposite axle.

If you have a digital camera (or a cell phone
with a built-in camera) snap a picture before
you start disassembling everything.

That way, you'll have a ready reference guide
of how things should look when they go back
together.
Step 3.
Lay out your spare tire, jack, and lug wrench.

Many tires feature a locking lug nut to guard
against theft.

To remove, use the special key tool—the
car's manual will specify where it's located.
Step 4.

Most lug nuts follow the righty-tighty/lefty-loosey
rule.

Attach the lug wrench to a nut, and turn the
wrench counterclockwise.

Repeat with each lug nut until all the nuts
are loosened.
Step 5.

Refer to the owner's manual for the best spot
to place the jack—typically along the frame,
very close to the flat tire.

Jack the car up until the wheel is off the
ground.
Never get under the car when it's on a jack.

Since it's fairly unstable in this position,
keep other people away until the car is safely
on the ground.
Step 6.

Remove the lug nuts one at a time, and keep
them together in a spot where they won't roll
away or disappear.
Then remove the flat.
Step 7.
Mount the spare tire onto the wheel lugs.

You may need to jack the car up some more
to slip on the spare tire.
Check the tire pressure on your spare regularly.
That way, it won't be flat when you need it.
Step 8.
Replace one lug nut at a time.

Begin tightening each by hand, then continue
with the lug wrench.

Lower your car to the ground, and finish tightening
the lugs in opposite pairs, to ensure uniform
pressure.
Once you're done, replace the hubcap.
Step 9.

Remove the objects blocking the wheels, and
place the tools and the flat tire in your
trunk.
Step 10.

Your wheel is ready, but you won't be able
to drive as quickly on a spare.

Check your owner's manual or the tire itself
to determine the spare's top speed, and get

yourself to the nearest garage so they can
patch or replace your tire!

Did you know In Texas Hold 'em, a "flat tire"
means you were initially dealt a jack and
a four – in any suit.

title: Change a Tire
content: hi I'm John Nielsen with triple-a today we're talking about buying and maintaining your tires and in this segment we're going to talk specifically about changing a flat tire now this may seem a little bit contrived and that's because it is we brought my car into the shop because this is a safe environment and will allow me to show you the steps involved in changing the flat at the roadside you'll want to make sure that you're in a safe position that traffic can see you that you're well away from the flow of traffic and that you're on a solid surface jacking up a car on a soft surface sand dirt anything like that can allow the car to actually fall off of the jack and can result in severe personal injury so if you cannot get safely off of the road if there's high traffic if you're in an area that you don't feel as stable the grounds not hard now is not the time to try to change your tire call for some assistance similarly if you feel uncomfortable with any of the steps we're about to go through it's another great time to call a professional there's no sense getting hurt over changing a spare tire now assuming that we're as far off the road as we can that we placed a triangle if we have one in the trunk of our car to alert traffic there's a breakdown ahead we have set the emergency brake we've set our emergency flashers we're going to talk about actually changing the tire the first thing we want to do is pull the owner's manual out of the glove box that's going to show us step-by-step how to change the tire you'll also highlight any safety features we need to know about the owners manual tells us to put a wheel chock behind the wheel now this is usually not included with the vehicle so it's something you're going to have to purchase and keep in the trunk before you find yourself at the roadside once we understand what needs to be done in the car we're going to go to the back of the car the trunk or the hatch and actually remove the spare tire the jack and if there's locks on the wheels themselves the key for that should be in the trunk or would be in the glove box we're going to get all that together and come on back to the front of the car we're going to loosen the lug nuts and then we'll place the jack under the vehicle where it's indicated in the owners mango and jack up the car you'll jack up the vehicle to get it far enough off the ground to allow you to remove the fire you'll remove the lug nuts by hand then you'll remove your tire and set it at the roadside next what I'll do is take my rag and wipe down the threads and the vacuum plate on the wheel this makes sure that there's no corrosion you install your spare tire install the lug nuts finger tight you would lower the jack and then tighten your lug nuts in a pattern indicated in your owner's manual failure to properly torque and install the lug nuts can cause the wheel or the brakes themselves to begin to warp and cause problems later on now a couple of things you noticed I had a set of gloves with me and a rag and also something to kneel down on this is something like keeping the trunk just in case I end up at the roadside it's a great thing for you to keep in and maybe a towel or sheet or a blanket to kneel on it the roadside or even to put your spare tire in when you're done these are little tips that will pay off if you ever need to get it done the final step in our procedure is to go visit our tire dealer have our tire repaired or replaced as necessary so now we've covered how to buy and maintain your tires I hope that you have a better understanding of what's involved in buying a tire and selecting the right tire for what you do and also how to change your tire at the roadside additional tips to keep everyone safe thank you very much

title: Change a Tire
content: today we're going to talk about how to jack up your Ford Ranger and pull off the rear tire so that you can replace it with a new tire and here you see the first thing you got to do is pull off these Center hub caps and these are made of plastic and aluminum so they're pretty delicate make sure that you use a crowbar that's got a plastic or a rubber coating on it so it doesn't damage the caps and here you see him pulling off each nut one by one in a random fashion here I'm just trying to get these nuts loose while there's still some tension with the tire on the ground and these haven't been changed out and a long time so you can see they're pretty rusty and it takes a lot of force and that's really the main reason to do this before you Jack the car up so that you have that extra force with the tire being against the ground once these are loose enough to be able to turn by hand then you can move on to jacking up the car and if you still got the original tire replacement equipment with your Ford Ranger then you've got a jack that looks like this which moves the whole car up and down depending on if you're turning this wheel here clockwise or counterclockwise and you should also have these extender bars here as well which which fit right into the jack and what you're looking at here is your car tire wrench which also has a small hole in it that you can use with the extender bars so that you don't have to be directly underneath the car when you're jacking it up now here you see me placing a bottle jack underneath the point in the rear of the car that you should use to jack up your car now this is important because you want to make sure you don't use some other part of the frame or some other soft metal that you believe can support the weight of the car because it probably can't and here I am off to the side now jacking the car up slowly and it's at about this point you begin to see the rear tire move a little bit and it starts to move more and more as the car goes up so we don't want to get the tire to eye off the ground maybe an inch or two just enough to get the old tire off and get another one on there and you can see him just now using my hands to pull those nuts off the rest of the way and in an ideal world you'd have some car jack stands here to support the weight of the car in case for any reason as I'm pulling the tire on the car falls off the jack but as you can see I don't have one available right now and that would be a normal safety precaution and as you can see it's a pretty rusty wheel sometimes it takes a little bit of kicking and force to pull it off but as you can see this one just comes right off and here you're watching me put a replacement tire into position so that the holes in the wheel match up with the bolts and once I get those bolts into the holes I don't have to worry about the car falling on me anymore and in part two I show how to tighten up the nuts so that you can be sure the tire won't wall up your car while you're driving thanks for watching

title: Change a Tire
content: ah in this installment what we're going to be covering is how to change a tire with the tools in your car I took the initiative and called the Ohio State Patrol on this just to find out what the safest way to do this is should you find yourself in a situation where you have a blowout on the highway most highly recommended course of action is to get off the highway completely you don't want to be doing this on the side of the road especially on a highway where people are traveling at a high rate of speed if you absolutely have to pull off the road what you want to do is get over as far to the right as possible first thing to do is to press your hazard switch that's usually located on the dashboard as a red triangle in addition to that you can purchase reflectors or road flares that you could put out just to alert other drivers that yes there is somebody with a disabled vehicle and don't hit them don't worry and if you have triple-a or you know really big boyfriend or then yeah by all means contact them and have them do it for you if you don't feel comfortable doing this but should you be in a situation where you absolutely have to do this then I would go about it this way another thing you want to consider before jacking up the vehicle is putting the parking brake on now normally spare tires are located in a trunk or in the case of this car they're located in the hatch we're usually located under some kind of access I'm going to open this one this is normally where you would find your spare tire these are the tools that you will need to work the jack and to get the wheel off we're going to pretend that this tire is flat now here's something else to note and that is that many times when you get your vehicle serviced check the air pressure not only in all of your tires but also in your spare tire unfortunately this rarely gets done so you may have to specially request this and in some cases you may have to pay a little more to have it done because should you ever need it and it doesn't have any air in it you're really just wasting your time one of the reasons why it doesn't get done all that often is because in order to fill this up you have to take it out of the car and you can do your technician a favor by taking all the stuff out of your trunk I can't tell you how many times somebody's asked me to check the air in their spare tire and they've got you know 100 pounds of topsoil back a golf clubs dirty clothes phone books ak-47s no that was an ar-15 sorry yeah all kinds of things in your trunk so you want to make sure that if you are having somebody perform this for you to remove your personal items from the trunk ahead of time that would be very helpful a lot of times they'll say run on the outside of the tire itself in this case it says inflate to 60 psi a lot of these instructions are also found in your owner's manuals and also a list of warnings here on this car the jack is kind of in a goofy place but I'm going to show you how to get it out of here it's located in the back here over by where the tire was and what you can do is look for the side with the adjuster for this and then just twist it and this should bring it down to the foyer you can take it out now that you have the tire out of the vehicle what you need to do is you need to get the damaged tire off of the car get your lug wrench out and this little guy you'll need this too the next thing you need to do is loosen the lug nuts you don't want to jack the car up first thing you want to loosen the lug nuts if you Jack this wheel up ahead of time here I'll show you what happened that's not gonna help you so the first thing we're going to do is we're going to try to take the lug nuts off now this seems rudimentary to say in order to loosen things you turn them counterclockwise in order to tighten things you turn them clockwise these lug nuts may be on very very tight so you may not be able to get these loose like this in fact it's not very likely that you will so there's one of two methods that I'm going to show you our first method is to stand on that's method one now you may not have the weight to overcome this so I'm going to show you something that if you're very careful about doing you can do this but if you're in a pinch you can use the weight of the car on the lug wrench and your jack now what you want to do is position the jack in such a way it's going to come in contact with the bottom of the lug wrench like this try to make sure that this fits in this little notch right here and what that's going to do in effect is use the weight of the car to overcome how tight and lug nut is now if you wonder what this little hooky thing is for see how this is getting towards the end keep an eye here to make sure this doesn't come flying off it may get violent but that is that is an alternative method using no strength but gravity to loosen a lug nut you may have to try this more than once because you're going to need to get it in just the right position in order for this to work I'm going to loosen the rest of these in the conventional foot method now that you have all the lug nuts loose it's time to Jack the car up now there's a couple of points on cars modern modern cars usually seem to have these points and some vehicles actually have arrows pointing to these areas and there's also diagrams in some cases that show you where the jack points are for the car in this case you see this reinforced area right here right here is another area what you want to do is position a jack under this area so that this knotch fits right under this so it kind of cradles itself in there this is called the scissor jack usually a good way to get these offices to give them a little a little hit but sometimes wheels get stuck on the hubs and sometimes you have to kick them pretty hard if you're unable to get the wheel off the car which does happen sometimes particularly with the aluminum wheels what you can do is you can put the lug nuts back on but don't tighten them all the way leave them a little bit loose drive the car for a few feet or whatever you have to do and a lot of times the weight of the car will break them loose these scissor jacks can be very precarious you want to be very careful not to knock the car off the jack because if you do it will hurt you pretty bad and you don't want a bad situation to get worse but the next step is to put the wheel on okay now that you have the new tire on you want to let the weight of the vehicle off the jack so you want to bring the jack down again okay now that you've got the vehicle back down on the ground and it's solid you want to tighten the lug nuts one final time tighten in a clockwise direction you don't need to tighten these things so much that you're never going to be able to get the wheel off again just make them snug you've got enough leverage with with the lug wrench that it should be okay now that you have your spare tire mounted and take the other tire and put in your trunk is probably the most logical place to put it I hope this helps you should you be stranded with a flat tire at some time just the bullet points get off the highway if it's at all possible drive it off the highway loosen lug nuts before you jack the car up tighten lug nuts after you let the car down using the jack to possibly lose some lug nuts if you need to don't drive around for an extended period of time on these spares they're not designed to be tires they're designed to get you someplace to where you can either get your tire repaired or replaced but I hope that this bit of information was helpful to you if you have any questions or comments leave them down here or you can visit me at eric the car guy comm thank you have a great day yeah this is gonna be fun you might just learn something

title: Change a Tire
content: everyone its Kayla here with Don Jacobs Honda and today I'm here with Calvin one of our Honda certified technicians he's going to show you all how to change a tire on your Honda vehicle first things first you got to get the tools out of your trunk your your Jack your lug nut tool put it put the jack and it should be twisting to your right to extend it should be able to easily twist it by hand until you get to the actual car and you want to put it on this little lift point which is a little rectangular point where you can lift it up then you take your hook put it into the actual jack put your jack on the end here we're going to make sure the tires always clear the ground your e brake is set so that you can loosen the lug nuts fairly easily pull your tire off open your trunk lid spin your actual spare tire holder off pull your tire out it helps to put your foot underneath a bit to lift it up line up here your studs put all your lug nuts back on make sure they're tight preferably in a star pattern now take your jacket off just do the reverse order what you did prior spin it to the left all right Thank You Calvin remember guys your spare tire is only gonna be a temporary fix also here's a few small things you can keep in your car that'll be helpful in changing your spare tire first of all a flashlight you ever have to change your tire at night it'll help you see what you're doing next a trash bag it's small compact it can be laid out on the ground when changing your tire to help keep your clothes clean and dry also we have here a kneeling pad you can find this at most Harmon garden stores and again it'll help protect your knees and your clothes while changing your tire remember if you all have any other questions feel free to visit us here at the dealership where you can find us online at dawn Jacob salon.com

title: Change a Tire
content: how to properly change a tire on a 97 Honda Civic secure the vehicle start by putting the emergency brake on then put some kind of block or wedge under the tire that its opposite of the tire you will be changing for the location of your spare tire and jack refer to the owner's manual you should have a spare tire a jack and the tire iron that is usually located in a bag and remember to wear gloves so you do not cut your hands the jack is placed in a specific spot depending on which tire you are changing this can also be found any owners manual your jack should come with a j-hook that allows you to raise and lower the jack you will insert the end of the j-hook into the notch on the tire iron raise the jack until the tire is approximately two to three inches off the ground next take the tire iron to remove the lug nuts by turning counterclockwise remove the flat tire put the spare tire on hand tighten the lug nuts first so the tire won't wobble around on you take the tire iron and slightly tighten the lug nuts in a crisscross pattern then do this once more to make sure the tire is secure remove the jack and return the tools and flat tire to the trunk drive to the nearest tire center to get your flat tire fixed

title: Change a Tire
content: here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire the compact spare tire jack and jack handle are stowed under the rear load floor in the trunk lift up the load floor cover and remove the hold down to remove the spare tire now you can remove the scissors jack and lug wrench as an assembly turn the jacks drew to the left to loosen the lug wrench and remove the wrench from the jack assembly go ahead now and loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas also make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set blocking both the front and rear of the wheel diagonally opposite of a jacking position is also a good idea for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire there is a front and rear jacking location on each side of the vehicle place the jack underneath the lift area that is closest to the flat tire turn the jack screw clockwise to firmly engage the jack saddle with the lift area do not raise the vehicle until you are sure that jack is fully engaged now you're ready to raise the vehicle by turning the jackscrew to the right raise the vehicle only until the tire just clears the surface and enough clearance is obtained to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and remove the lug nuts and wheel position the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly reinstall the lug nuts with a cone-shaped end toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jackscrew to the left and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has tighten twice maximum effort should be used for final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go please refer to the instruction manuals on the owners information DVD or dodge com / en / owners / manuals for complete details and other important safety information

a 37 1250 BF goodrich all-terrain TKO to their brand new tire for the all-terrain and what I use to go off-road and much of the area that I explore so today primarily I'm going to be talking about the factors that you'll have to deal with when being one in the middle of nowhere to having a lifted or larger full-size truck and three having a larger tire but only using stock factory tire replacement kits don't forget before you start doing anything on your truck you're going to want to put your emergency brake firmly on a couple of the things that you're going to want to consider when traveling with a full-size and lifted truck are having a spare on hand that matches the size of your new set of tires blocks of wood sturdy and large enough to hold the weight of the truck when you have to actually jack it up higher than it was sold now because your truck isn't a new height and your axle is a bit higher off the ground that was when you got it you're going to want to put a piece of wood in here in order to make up for the gap between the ground and your axle which used to be a little bit closer the again we want to take your factory jack get it raised up as much as possible in advance and then place it safely and firmly on top of the block of wood with the key hole facing towards the back because that's exactly where you're going to access it with the jack rod now that we have the tire up off the ground we can remove the lug nuts using the lug nut key and the stock tire iron now roll in your spare do your best to line up the holes with the bolts it's easiest if you put the top two on top and then just slide it in bouncing it off those finger tighten all the lug nuts then using the tire iron tighten them until they are completely firm one thing you might want to keep tool and install the last bolt you Snug each of the bolts but don't fully tighten them at this time you lower the jack and remove it tighten the lug bolts tighten the bolts in a star or crisscross title: Change a Tire
content: here's a few tips for changing your tire first have it in park and on level ground also set your emergency brake once the brake is set each car has a spare tire somewhere hidden and a jack this one's underneath the liner in the trunk you can use your tire iron to take off the hubcaps be careful they can break on the other side of your iron is the socket and loosen all the bolts don't remove them just loosen them then slip the hook into the jack and if you look at your jack there's some markings underneath it on Toyota's to show you where to put your Jack there's two little markings for each wheel and lift the tire off the ground about one inch and take off all the bolts and place the new tire on and put the bolts on by hand once each bolt is a little bit snug use your iron and then tighten diagonally from ball to ball until you get all five and tighten all of them with the same amount of force once you've done all five start over from the first again and give it a little bit more of a tweak then lower the jack till the tires on the ground and tighten the bolts the rest of the way again going in the star pattern diagonally give it a lot of force and lastly when you put the hub cap back on don't block the valve stem the part where you fill in your tires with air and that's it hope this helped Thanks

title: Change a Tire
content: hello my name is Kevin and today I'm going to show you how to remove a spare tire and use it to replace a flat tire on your 2015 Toyota Sienna let's get started so we're going to go ahead and start in the rear of the vehicle where most of the equipment is located you have this little pull tab right here just pull on that and this side panel will come out nice and easy we'll go ahead and start with the extension arm that has a hook on the end of it this long piece here next to that you have the socket with an eyelet on the top those two will be used together to lower the spare tire next you have the strap which is used to secure the flat tire in the back of the vehicle and last the instruction manual here as well now still in the vehicle you have your jack which is going to take a little bit of muscle to get out it's in there pretty secure and next to the jack is your tire iron that's going to be used to loosen and tighten the lug nuts on your tire as well we'll go ahead and take all that out so we have all of the equipment out of the vehicle we'll just do a quick recap there's your jack right there the biggest piece on on the ground there and then next to that is your tire iron which you'll use to loosen and tighten your lug nuts next to the tire iron is your extension arm with the hook on the end and that will be used with the socket with an eyelet on it to lower your spare tire off of the bottom of the sienna and so those are kind of one package together those will be used together and then the tire iron is separate from that and then you also use the extension arm with the jack to raise the jack up underneath the vehicle and we'll show you that in a little bit now we're going to go ahead and lower your spare tire to do that you will need your extension arm as well as your socket we're going to go ahead and move back the captain's chair on the passenger side of the vehicle to expose this little cutout in your carpet now you may have to move your floor mats out of the way to be able to see this cut out but once you make it visible you're going to go ahead and just peel back the carpeting and the insulation while you have that held back we're going to go ahead and take our socket and place it right on top of the bolt head it should be a nice snug fit because it is the correct size go ahead and take your extension arm with the hook end and go ahead and just attach it right to that socket is going to allow you to use the extension arm to lower the spare tire we're going to just rotate it nice and easy remember to always rotate in a counterclockwise direction or lefty loosey if you prefer and we're going to go ahead and rotate until it actually stops rotating as you're rotating down this is what it's going to look like underneath your vehicle now this is sped up a little bit it will not actually lower this fast but it just shows you that you will need all the slack in the line it's not just till the tire touches the ground but you will need the slack in the line as well now once we have the tire on the ground we're going to go ahead and just pull that out using the slack that's in the line I'm going to tilt the tire up here so you can see the little lock that's on the end all you have to do is take that lock that's right there and turn it sideways and feed it back through the spare tire this will allow you to then use the spare tire obviously on the outside of your vehicle but you do have to turn it sideways punch it back through like that and then you're all ready to go to use the spare tire so on the Toyota Sienna we do have five lug nuts we're going to go ahead and loosen all five of these lug nuts just a simple half a turn before we jack up the vehicle so you're going to take your tire iron and it doesn't matter in which order you loosen the lug nuts you just simply go around and loosen each one half a turn and they should be tight obviously so it does take a little bit of muscle to go ahead and loosen those now that we have them loosened we're going to go ahead and be ready to jack up our vehicle this is the jack that came with the sienna and we're going to go ahead and show you how to raise up the jack so there's this little loop on the end of the jack and you're actually going to use the same extension arm that you used to lower the spare tire you simply just take the hook end of the extension arm and place it through that loop and now when you rotate the extension arm it's going to go ahead and raise the jack up so now I'll show you where to place the jack underneath your sienna now I'm going to show you where to place your jack when you're raising your sienna you're going to go ahead and notice this tire right there that's the rear tire that we just loosen the lug nuts on you can see the mud flap notice this little Tang metal that sticks down from the frame this little tang of metal is what the jack is going to be sitting on you'll notice these two indents right there and the tang of metal that lets show where the jack needs to be sitting so this tang of metal is actually going to fit inside this little slit that's within the jack so you place your jack in a position to where the loop on the end of the jack is facing outward so you can use the extension arm to raise the jack and the jack will be raised right up on that tang the jack has now been raised up against the vehicle and now to raise your vehicle you're going to go ahead and take the hook end of your extension arm just place it in that little loop and go ahead and rotate clockwise to go ahead and lift the vehicle up you can see the vehicle is raising up and now I'll go ahead and look at it from a side profile you can see the tire raising up and you just need some daylight under that tire and you're good to go so now you can see our jack is right there and our tire freely spins because it's high enough off the ground now since we loosen these lug nuts they should be pretty easy to take off and you can go ahead and just loosen them by hand I went ahead and sped this up a little bit once you have all the lug nuts loosened off the tire you're going to go ahead and be able to remove that flat tire now our spare tire is ready to go ahead and be put on you want to make sure you're putting your spare tire on in the right direction which means the fill nipple for the spare tire is supposed to be facing outward that way if you were to need to fill your spare tire you are able to do so even though the spare tire should already be filled so we'll go ahead and put the spare tire right on those studs may take a little bit of working once you have the spare tire on there you're going to use the same five lug nuts that came off your other tire and go ahead and fit them right on the spare now to tighten them up you do want to use a star pattern and so you don't go in a complete circle but instead you go on a star so you're going to use your tire iron to tighten them up as tight as they can go and then we're going to go ahead and lower the vehicle making sure that the tire is not touching the ground so you have some traction and you can get some force now you're going to want to go around first and just lightly tighten each lug nut in a star pattern making sure you're not going in a circle but rather a star so skipping one one lug nut every time and then you go around a second time and applying quite a bit of force to those lug nuts so that is how you change a tire on your 2015 Toyota Sienna from Metro Toyota I'm Kevin to look at other how-to videos please check out our video page I hope you enjoyed this video and like always have a good day

gap by prying it open using the track rod this is the wrench use this for removing the scroll before removing the screws you will have to loosen them for loosening the screws use your feet as doing it very important once you have connected all the bolts first tighten them using your fingers then use the wrench to tighten as much as you can with the strength of your hands now using the wrench rod title: Change a Tire
content: [Music] here's hoping you'll never have to but just in case let's talk about changing a flat tire now even after you watch this video you should still check your owner's manual for more details about proper jack placement and use the Jack and Jack tools are stored under the front passenger seat if your vehicle features air suspension use the instrument cluster display or your UConnect system if equipped to activate tire jack mode to access the Jack and Jack tools you must remove the plastic access cover located on the side of the seat to remove the cover pull the front part of the cover closest to the front of the seat toward you to release a locking tab once the front of the cover is loose slide the cover toward the front of the seat until it is free from the seat frame remove the jack and tools by removing the wing bolt and sliding the assembly from under the seat remove the spare tire before attempting to jack up the truck attach the lug wrench to the Jack extension to make sure the spring clip in each extension tube section clicks together in the mating extension to the handle comprised of all the extension tubes locks at all positions except the lug wrench attachment insert the tube through the access hole between the lower tailgate and the type of the bumper and into the winch mechanism to rotate the lug wrench handle left or counterclockwise until the spare tire is on the ground with enough cable slack that you can pull it out from under the vehicle when the spare is clear tilt the retainer at the end of the cable and pull it through the center of the wheel now loosen but do not remove the wheel lug nuts by turning them to the left one turn while the wheel is still on the ground be aware that your vehicle may have locking lug nuts and require use of an included special tool now make sure you're parked on a firm level surface safely away from traffic avoid ice or slippery areas the jack itself should be level two there should be no one inside the vehicle make sure the ignition is off the hazard lights are on and the parking brake is fully set never start the engine when the vehicle is up on the jack stay clear of the area below the vehicle when using the jack or changing the tire it's a good idea to block the front and rear of the tire diagonally opposite of the jacking position for example if changing the right front tire block the left rear tire now look for the proper jacking locations for a front wheel place the scissor jack under the rear portion of the lower control arm with the handle extended diagonally toward the rear of the vehicle for a rear wheel place the jack under the axle between the wheel and the shock bracket with the handle extended to the rear of the vehicle now you're ready to raise the vehicle before you connect the handle to the check make sure the jack is directly below the proper lift point then use your fingers to turn the jack screw to the right or clockwise to raise the jack until it's securely seated under the lift point the center line of the jack should sit right on the center line of the axle don't Jack at an angle or you could ruin the jack and tire kit now use the jack handle assembly to raise the vehicle keep the handles in line with a jack to minimize lifting effort and to insure Jack function raise the vehicle until you've got just enough clearance to install the spare tire remember minimum tire lift provides maximum stability okay now go ahead and finish removing the lug nuts in wheel place the spare tire on the vehicle with the valve stem facing out the vehicle could be damaged if the spare tire is mounted incorrectly now reinstall the lug nuts with the cone-shaped and toward the wheel lightly tighten the lug nuts clockwise now you can lower the vehicle by turning the jack screw to the left or counterclockwise and remove the jack once on the ground you can finish tightening the lug nuts alternate lug nuts until each lug nut has been tightened twice maximum efforts should be used for the final tightening of the lug nuts it's always a good idea to have the tightness checked with a torque wrench by your authorized dealer or at a service station now just secure the tire jack and tools in their proper locations and you're ready to go this video is not intended to take the place of your owner's manual for complete details and other important safety information please see your owner's information

title: Change a Tire
content: so you have a flat tire not to worry changing it is easy and only takes a few minutes first make sure your emergency brake is engaged this will prevent the vehicle from rolling next locate your spare and Jack these can usually be found in the trunk lay out your tools so they're easy to reach locate the pinch weld for the body and frame meat slide the jack underneath and raise it until it touches the weld [Music] loosen the lug nuts just a bit then jack up the car make sure the tire has completely lifted off the ground now remove the lug nuts and the flat tire [Music] put on the spare and replace the lug nuts lower the car until the tire makes contact with the ground tighten the nuts in a star pattern this ensures that the tire goes on straight drop the car down the rest of the way and you're good to go [Music] remember engage the ebrake place the jack under the pinch weld make sure the tire has cleared the ground and tighten the lug nuts in a star pattern for more tips visit youtube.com slash onto west TV [Music]

title: Change a Tire
content: make sure your vehicle is parked in a safe location a low traffic parking lot or large pave pull out well off any busy street or road is ideal set the emergency brake first if you have a manual transmission put your car in first gear if your vehicle is an automatic just put it in park next place wheel chocks or big rocks behind and in front of the tire opposite the one being changed this will prevent vehicle movement and the jack from slipping while we work next find your lug wrench jack and spare tire these tools are often located in the trunk under the carpeting your vehicle's manual will indicate exactly where they are this only applies if your vehicle has a hubcap many hubcaps just snap into place but some are held on by the lug nuts you can usually pry them off using something flat like a screwdriver if your vehicle has covers over the lug nuts be sure to remove them as well loosen the first lug nut by rotating the wrench counterclockwise just once without removing the lug nut entirely then loosen the second nut directly opposite of the first one and then the one opposite that like a star-shaped pattern if the lug nuts are tight use your body weight to push down look in your owners manual for where to position the jack it's often under the frame near the tire with the flat but not always the case our jack should be aligned with a thin seam line that runs under the vehicle the factory jack has a notch cut out of it for a specific fit next insert the handle and turn it clockwise to raise the car lower the jack if at any point your car seems unstable and never ever get under a car that is only supported by a jack now fully remove the lug nuts and place them in a secure location grasp the tire with two hands and pull it straight out then place it under the car this is a precautionary measure just in case the jack slips remove any aftermarket accessories like hub rings at this point the valve stem on the spare tire should be facing out then align it with the wheel studs and push it into the assembly tighten one lug nut by hand follow the same star pattern used to remove the lug nuts remove the flat tire from underneath the vehicle turn the Jack handle counterclockwise and lower the vehicle once the vehicle is firmly grounded fully tighten the lug nuts using your wrench again in the star shaped pattern remember to gather your tools back in place remove the wheel Chuck's and place your flat tire in the trunk lug nuts and lug bolts should be torqued to factory specs you can also reach out to a local discount tire for proper torque recommendations for your vehicle finally remember that spare tires are smaller and less capable than regular tires they should only be used for limited short distance driving visit your nearest discount tire store for tire inspections repairs and replacements and to learn more about how to change your tires you can also visit us online at discount tire comm thanks for watching make sure you subscribe to the discount tire channel and also check out these other cool videos you

car precedent and you can see the you can see the tire how it's very the tread is very worn down and we need to replace that first thing you're going to want to do is to take the wheel cover off which we've just done and before you Jack the golf cart up you're going to want to take the lug nuts a little bit loose because there's quite a bit of force is required to break them loose and once you jack the golf cart up the wheel will be in the air and it will spin freely it will be very difficult to break the wheel lugs loose at that point so the first thing take off your wheel cover and then you want to take your wheel lugs loose the size of the the wheel lug nuts on most golf carts is going to be require a 3/4 inch socket a 3/4 inch socket and then you're going to want to place the jack appropriately underneath the golf cart and if you don't have a jack most of the local auto parts stores today will loan you the tools we've got the golf cart on the lift because I wanted to be able to show you where to place the jack you proceed Chris has got the jack underneath the golf cart he's placed it right underneath the aluminum frame you can see the frame right here you'll want to place your jack underneath your aluminum frame you do not want to place it underneath plastic because the plastic will give you'll end up bending the plastic cracking it breaking it so you need to make sure that when you place the jack underneath the golf cart that you get it underneath frame you remove the wheel lugs it's lefty loosey real nice easy thing to remember lefty loosey righty tighty so you want to turn the wheel lug nuts to the left in order to take them off you'll need to take the four lug nuts off alright so we have our wheel lugs off Chris is now going to remove the old wheel and then place the new wheel on the hub line up your four holes with your four four wheel studs and then you're going to start your your lug nuts again you're going to turn them to the right righty-tighty lefty-loosey and righty tighty so you'll want to go ahead and draw them down as much as you can before you lower the jack the thing that I failed to mention about placing the jack underneath the golf cart is that you'll want to make sure you use a safety stand if you don't have one perhaps you've got some pieces of wood that you can stack or a concrete block something that protects you in case the jack slips and falls you won't get hurt alright so Chris has got the four wheel lug nuts brought up and now we're going to remove the jack so that we can torque tighten torque the wheel lugs he show us the torque wrench he's got a torque wrench in his hand and you'll want to you'll want to make sure you properly torque the wheel lug nuts Chris what do you normally torque them at they're around 100 foot pounds okay if he's going to go ahead and talk for huh and when you torque them you want to torque them in a crisscross pattern and when I say crisscross I mean what you're going to tighten one and you go directly opposite of the other and then you're going to tighten that one and then kind of like a star pattern except for you can go straight across from each other and after you torque them then you just put your wheel cover back on check your air pressure and you're good to go when you go to put the wheel cover back on you'll want to make sure that you line up the hole for the air valve the tire air valve as you can see Chris has got it lined up and once you line it up just the simple pop and puts it on and there you go that's how you change a wheel on a club car precedent this video has been brought to you by BestBuy golf carts locate us on the web at BestBuy golf carts calm thanks for watching

title: Change a Tire
content: welcome to another minutes with mean Z today we're going to go over how to change a tire if you get a flat on a turret bit of a different animal the spare tire comes deflated you take the tire out you inflate it and then you put it on your vehicle so here's your spare tire this is actually a tool to unbolt a securing bolt here's your compressor here's the tow hook this is an aligning tool a wrench to take off the lug nuts tire chocks so your vehicle doesn't move once you lift it up you have to hook up the compressor your positive terminal negative terminal take your compressor that right on the end of the valve cap and then the fun begins it needs to be filled up to 50 psi or a 3.5 bar both of those are displayed on the compressor first find the jacking point of the vehicle there's what they call a jack flap take that off what's like that it just clips in and underneath there is a frame rail to Jack vehicle up and chock the vehicle so doesn't roll the next step is to remove the lug caps and now before jacking up the vehicle just crack loose the lug bolts this is going to go right into the lip jack put it under there kit okay you can see we got clearance under the tire okay at this point this is when you're going to want to take your alignment tool out and you just put it in one of the holes you took the lug bolts out and then you take your last lug bolt out get the tire off the vehicle get your spare tire and put it right onto the line man so once you got them all kind of hand snug we can locally let the vehicle back down alright and then you just want to tighten down you want to go on a star pattern just so it's on there evenly you're only going to be able to get a certain amount of torque on this okay and after you get all done get back on the road want to get to the dealer as soon as you can just to get your torque and the pressure checked on the vehicle for safety have a good one

title: Change a Tire
content: good morning I'm bill Bergey with adventure rider magazine I'm out here with James Pratt and Shannon Markel we are in Logan Utah on our way to the redmond rally the BMW International Rally in Oregon and we're going to do a presentation on changing the rear tire on a BMW r1200gs adventure a couple of things we'll do before we start I like to kind of secure things for safety I've got a this is basically a packing strap that the motorcycles come in tied to my chest and into my front wheel and then I'm going to secure the front brake also a couple of little things to keep this box and coming off this understand as we move ahead on this you'll see why it might do that other than the mind that they tend to have of their own sometimes all right let the air out of the front tire and I keep a valve core extractor on the valve cap I also keep a spare in my tool kit more convenient the better seems like you're always looking for one of these okay we're going to break the tire down now the 1200 GS comes with a built in braking tool and that works quite well in most cases that is why you secure your Center stand and your front brake just a little bit of forward movement and that thing will come off of there and you'll be chasing it down the hill or caught under it people fight these and fight them and they're just really not that difficult to get off with a good technique okay okay when we're changing the tire it's a good idea to usually start and end at the valve stem in particular if you've got will tire pressure sensors built into the machine like this it's kind of a large lump in there you don't to break that off so you get the tire clear of that too before you ever get started so we'll get a tire tool started in that area push the tire down into the channel feet and then you can break it over pretty easy to that point all you have to do just pop it off now when I change my tires i lubricate the bead with silicone every time if you know providing a habited available it makes this a lot easier I've bought them a little bit to get them off but this tire is completely worn out as you can see and you know it popped right on okay we're mounting a cotton LT kcat back in place of a worn out continental tee kcat 2,500 miles of heavy throttle use on that tire these are considered a directional tire so you want to make sure your arrow lines up with logic and the direction of rotation so here again you're going to start we're going to end at the valve core about sim so push the tire in place and then we'll go back to the bottom again and it's on now we're going to re-inflate this I'm using a little slime 12-volt air pump and there are times when these beats don't want to match and seal to the extent that they need to so that you can get the tire to re-inflate if that happens you can take this band right here or some similar band and wrap it around the tire scrunch it down with a stick or tire tire tool whatever you have to to push the tire in which will help to get the bead to see it also you can have a buddy cup compress it up here if you have one on hand but you are going to have to make it seal because these pumps don't provide any surge pressure that will help to get that tire started on to the bead let's see what kind of luck we get with okay so since that didn't work then we're going to have to use the strap and see if we can get lucky with this we'll wrap the strap on there a little pressure on it try not to break our strap it's pretty pretty tough as you can see that's compressing the tire down we ran the motor during the initial inflation so that we could pop the bead with the pump rpm with the extra alternator voltage we get a little bit more pump volume also we ran the area initially with the valve core out it's easier to flow the air inside that will put about Quran andrea plate the tire of the proper pressure and will start the motor 40 psi tire pressure like your mileage may vary I run about 36 in the front and 38 to 40 in the rear for road conditions I'm carrying a load like this with continuity kcat you can get a little bit of flex if you get the tire pressure much below that the low end of the tire pressure might be 6 8 psi short story I was out at Toronto pinnacles west of Death Valley last month and I went in an area that was a deep sand wash completely loaded bike went to the skid plate I was completely buried I unloaded the bike did all right things to get it out pushed as hard as I could push I couldn't influence the motorcycle it wasn't going anywhere so I let as a last resort air out of the tires both the front and the rear down to that 6 to 8 psi range stood beside the motorcycle a slight nudge let off the clutch and it pulled itself out almost completely under its own power it makes that much difference the idea of having an inflator with you not just co2 but an actual pump allows you to put the tires back up to reasonable pressures all the way up if you want to Road pressures so that you can continue on safely and we're done so this is where you say what about the front tire how do you do that with it on the center stand well it's a little bit more difficult to go that route it's good to have a buddy available but with a good set of tire tools you can usually work this tire off the bead will do the entire process in another video but I do just want to mention that when you do that be patient keep a heavy boot on the bead and protect your brake this

title: Change a Tire
content: if you spend any reasonable amount of time at all riding your bike you'll eventually experience a flat tire not to worry though with the proper equipment and just a little knowledge you'll have the flat change then you'll be back on the road in a couple of minutes as soon as you realize that you have a flat focus on controlling the bike first then signal to the riders behind you while you gently bring yourself to a stop if your rear tire is the problem shift to the smallest gear and your cassette click through a couple of years at a time and then turn the cranks with your hand in order to make the change shift open the brake callipers using the lever on the brake itself and then release the quick disconnect on the skewer do this by opening the disconnects lever and then spinning it counterclockwise several times once the quick disconnect is loosened the wheel should simply pop right out of the frame grab your tire levers out of your saddlebag and then set your bike aside while you're working on the tire hook your levers under the bead of the tire and pry it over the edge of the rim hook one lever to a spoke so that it doesn't move and pull the other one all the way around if you have a stubborn wheel you may need to do a little more prying than Jill does here once the tire is completely off on one side pull the tube out then fold it up so you can take it home in your Jersey pocket or your bag run your fingers around the inside of your tire to make sure there are no foreign objects inside that can flat your spare tube using the pump put enough air on the tube to make it manageable you can also simply blow some air in with your mouth if you don't have a pump place the new tube inside the tire starting at the valve stem then using your fingers place the tire back on the rim until you can no longer get the bead over the edge at that point use your tire levers to pry the tire all the way on be careful not to pinch the tube between the lever and the rim go all the way around the wheel checking to make sure that the tube is completely seated inside the tire using your hand pump or your co2 inflator air up the tire put the wheel back into the frame so that the chain is lying on the smallest beer in the cassette and shown here once the wheels lined up properly simply lower the frame down onto the wheel so that the skewer slides into the dropouts here's a view from another angle clamp the calipers back down and tighten the quick disconnect lever turn the crank with your hand to make sure that the wheel is on correctly and that the chain is content: I'm Mike Williams with lands camper man I'm here to show you the proper tire changing procedure on a Ford f250 350 and a 454 truck now 550 is done a little differently and I do recommend that you refer to the Ford owner's manual on the f250 350 450 and 550 as well as this instructional video now what you see here in front of me is the Ford supplied jack handles as well as the jack now the Jack handles include the lug wrench the jack handle itself as well as the spare tire removal tool now over here to your right you'll see the atwood jack remote that operates the atwood jacks on our lance camper as well as I have 1116 socket on a 3/8 drive ratchet to make it simpler and easier to remove the spare tire from the carrier and also we'll Chuck which is also important while changing a tire now the first thing we're going to do in this procedure is we're going to go ahead and chock the front tire we're going to be demonstrating by the way on the rear so we're going to chop the front tire here with the wheel chock so that the vehicle doesn't roll when we're jacking it up because if the vehicle rolls it can come off the jack and it could cause injury or death now the next procedure that we're going to go ahead and do is we want to take and get the weight of the camper off of the truck and also gain some clearance to remove the spare tire from the spare tire carrier so we're going to remove our happy jack tie-down from the truck and we'll want to remove all four of these tie-downs set that aside then we're going to go ahead and swing out the swing away if you have the swing away jack brackets on the front for the dually truck if you're working on a single rear wheel axle truck you won't have the swing away bracket so you won't have to perform this procedure so once you've done that you're going to want to go ahead and activate the Jack's and extend the jacks down to the ground extend all Jack's bring in the camper up off the ground itself we've got the jack in place we're going to want to lower the spare tire down from the spare tire carrier so what you're going to end up needing to do is you're going to need to get the key lock as well as the extension handle and install the key lock onto the extension handle then you're going to need an extension and depending on which wrench you're going to use either your ratchet wrench with the 1116 socket or the Ford provided jack alright a handle we're going to come on in back here we're going to go ahead and lower that now once you've gotten underneath the back of the camper here you want to go ahead and install the spare tire removal handle with the tool attached into the spare tire winch hole you're going to go ahead and put that inside shove it all the way into the channel you'll fill up a connection and lock into place you'll have a second extension you're going to apply to the original extension and then use your ratchet wrench once you got that on go ahead and lower the spare tire down to the ground so what we're going to end up doing is we're going to take the center cap off the center cap has four notches in it that's located up against the rim itself that's designed to take this hook that's provided with the Ford entire kit now the hook is insulated to protect the rim from getting damaged so you're going to go ahead and get this hook back into one of those brackets and once it's popped off go ahead and set it to the side now if you're working on the rear duel you're going to have to use this extension that's provided in the kit by four so that will go onto your lug nut just like so use your lug wrench and loosen your lip okay once you're done removing the lug nuts now it's time to Jack the truck up off the ground to get your tire up but you're going to end up doing is jacking it up until you have some clearance between the ground and the tire so that you get to proper distance so that you can remove the tire off the axle okay once you've got the truck jacked up off the ground and the tire has been raised then you can go ahead and pull the tire off of the truck go ahead and set that tire to the side grab your replacement tire now keep in mind tires are heavy so proper lifting procedures should be taken when you're doing the lifting of this tire I find it best if done put it on the center hub like so and voila once you got the tire on go ahead and reinstall the lug nuts when replacing a spare tire if it just happens to be the inside dually there's going to be a small diameter hole in the rim for the index there's a pin that is matted so that you get that aligned with the hub and the rim when installing the spare tire that has to be in place because you want to make sure that the rim is flush against the hub the full circumference of the hub now once we've got the lug nuts back on we want to Snug the lug nuts down to a point that they're slugged all of them before lowering it down to the ground and when you snug up lug nuts you want to go star wise so go across snug frost snug I tell each of over - tight against the rim once that's done then you're ready to lower the truck to the ground and then finish your final torque on the lug nuts and you want to torque the tired lug nuts tight Oh once the track attire is on the ground once they're tight then you're ready to go ahead backup everything and take it down to your local tire repair shop to have that spoon tire or that flat tire repaired and put on the back on the truck and get the spare tire mounted back up on the spare tire carrier so this is Mike Williams with Lance camp for manufacturing showing you the tire changing procedure on the Ford f-250 350 and 450 now 550 s again are different so please refer to the owners manual on all applications f250 350 and 450 and the 550 again this Mike Williams Lance camper Happy Camp
